predicate.note: Frames file for 'turn' based on Chris' old frames file and comparison to initial sentences of big corpus. Many, many made-up examples.

example.name: transitive agentive
example.text: John turned the key in the lock.

example.name: ergative
example.text: The focus turned to other fixed-income markets.

example.name: non-obvious direction
example.text: The reforms turned the economy around.

example.name: transitive
example.text: The plan turned state companies private.

example.name: with source/start state
example.text: John turned Mary from a reactionary to an activist.

example.name: ergative
example.text: John turned into an activist.

example.name: turn down, as direction
example.text: John turned down the heat.

roleset.name: idiomatic: turn thumbs down on = reject

example.name: this really does occur
example.text: The voters turned thumbs down on the proposed bill.

example.name: as the world turns?
example.text: Instead, it turns on the disputed and elusive facts of ``who did what to whom.''
example.arg: the disputed and elusive facts of ``who did what to whom

example.name: turn a prophet?
example.text: Why should they have to co-exist with opportunists rushing in *trace* to turn a quick profit?

predicate.note: Similar to the "rotation" roleset for "turn" above

example.name: transitive
example.text: John turned all applicants away.

example.name: ergative
example.text: John turned away from the stock market in disgust.

predicate.note: Similar to "rotation" roleset and also "turn away"

roleset.name: reject

example.name: transitive
example.text: Separately, the Federal Energy Regulation Commission turned down for now a request by Northeast seeking approval of its possible purchase of PS of New Hampshire.
example.arg: a request by Northeast seeking approval of its possible purchase of PS of New Hampshire

roleset.note:
Compare this to the literal (non-phrasal) "turn down" (turn.01): John turned down the covers on the bed. In this case, "down" is the ArgM-DIR.
"Turn down" also occurs in the "transformation" roleset (turn.02) of the non-phrasal "turn": John turned the heat down.

example.name: transitive
example.text: John turned the test in to his teacher.

example.name: tune in, turn on, drop out
example.text: But the genes were accompanied by a piece of DNA, called a promoter, that [*T*-2] turns the genes on.

example.name: transitive
example.text: John turned the lights off.

example.name: transitive
example.text: John turned Mary off on hot dogs.

example.name: transitive
example.text: John turned out the lights.

roleset.name: produce, create

example.name: transitive
example.text: This factory turns out hundreds of mountain bikes every day.

roleset.note: The higher-numbered args (2 & 3) may or may not occur; here they are just in case.

example.name: sentential arg
example.text: It turns out that John never reads the frames files.
example.arg: John never reads the frames files
example.note: As with "seem", ignore the meaningless "it", and as with all verbs-of-saying, ignore the complementizer "that".

example.name: split sentential arg
example.text: (In last week's rape case, for example, the girl turns out *trace* to have been a victim of incest.)
example.arg: [the girl] [*trace* to have been a victim of incest]

example.name: with attribute
example.text: But in the end, everything turns out for the best, in the film makers' warped view.
example.arg: in the film makers' warped view

example.name: glitterati
example.text: Among the glitterati who [*T*-1] turned out in bipartisan black-tie force [*-3] to benefit the Coelho Epilepsy Fund last month were [*T*-2] Sen. Robert Dole, Rep. Newt Gingrich, and other kingpins of Congress.
example.arg: [*-3] to benefit the Coelho Epilepsy Fund

predicate.note: Different from the directional "turn over" as in "John turned the rock over to see all the bugs underneath." (turn.01)

roleset.name: submit, give, exchange

example.name: transitive
example.text: John turned all the evidence over to the FBI.

example.name: as exchange
example.text: Such is his reputation among the East Bay Bashers that when he hit his first career home run last season, the fan who caught it agreed *trace* to turn the ball over to him in return for an autograph.

roleset.note: Adding the arg3 to this makes sentences really awkward--only sports writers would use it.

example.name: poof!
example.text: You never know where she'll turn up.

example.name: I said, 'poof'!
example.text: Though details were sketchy in the aftermath of the violent earthquake that shook the high-tech corridor along with the rest of the San Franciso Bay area, a spot check of computer makers turned up little, if any, potentially lingering damage to facilities or fabrication equipment.
example.arg: Though details were sketchy in the aftermath of the violent earthquake that shook the high-tech corridor along with the rest of the San Francisco area
a spot check of computer makers
little, if any, potentially lingering damage to facilities or fabrication equipment
